title: Apple vs Epic Aftermath: A New Era for Game DTC

rawLines.text: [Music]
Welcome to the Navit Gaming Podcast,
where it is our mission to explore the
business and future of video games. We
bring together the industry's brightest
builders, investors, and thinkers to
keep a pulse on current events, dissect
emerging trends and games, share lessons
learned, and have a great time.
This podcast is also part of Navik's
growing ecosystem which ranges from free
and premium research to consulting and
advisory services. For more information,
visit
[Music]
www.navic.co. This episode is brought to
you by Lightseed Venture Partners.
Lightseed is a globally leading venture
capital firm with over $29 billion in
capital under management and more than
500 investments across the US, Europe,
and Asia. With its dedicated gaming
practice, Lightseed Gaming, the firm is
investing from over $7 billion in early
and growth stage capital, making it by
far the largest fund focused on gaming
and interactive technology. Lightseed's
team combines deep expertise in gaming
with a global multi-stage investment
platform and a culture that truly puts
founders first. Selected investments
include Epic Games, Snap, and Stability
AI, as well as game designers and
producers who led the creation of titles
like Fortnite, Call of Duty, League of
Legends, Valerant, Starcraft 2, and many
more. For more information, simply go to
gaming.lsvp.com or check out the details
in the show notes. This episode is
brought to you by Overwolf. With over
1,500 games supported, 165,000 creators,
and 38 million monthly active users,
Overwolf is the guild for in-game
creators. Whether you're a gamer,
creator, or game studio, Overwolf is the
ultimate destination for integrating UGC
in games. For game studios, Overwolf
offers Curse Forge for studios, a white
label solution that lets game makers and
publishers easily integrate mods safely
and seamlessly into their games, both
existing and new, at zero cost. It's
battle tested by AAA studios and games,
including Maxis with The Sims 4, Studio
Wildcard with Ark, Take 2 Interactive,
and others. For creators, Overwolf is
the all-in-one platform that enables
creators to build, distribute, and
monetize in-game apps, mods, and game
servers. In 2022, Overwolf paid over
$160 million to in-game creators,
proving that they truly value the
talents and contributions of the gaming
community. You can check out everything
Overwolf has to offer at
overwolf.com or check out the details in
the show notes. And with that, let's
jump into the episode. Hello everyone.
I'm your host Devin Becker and today I'm
delighted to be joined by Chris F,
founder and CEO of Neon Commerce Inc.
sometimes known as Neon Pay as well. Uh
Neon is the complete direct consumer
commerce platform and merchant of record
for games. Always a fun thing to say.
They partner with mobile and PC studios
to help them save money, increase
revenue, and build closer relationships
with players. But today we've got a very
special topic that is a topical. Uh
today we're going to explore the broader
topic first of direct to consumer
alternative payments and web shops, but
it's all going to be in light of the
somewhat recent Epic versus Apple ruling
uh which you know just settled at the
end of April, but we want to talk a
little bit about what that means for
everyone going forward. But first off,
just to get things out of the way, can
you introduce yourself, your background,
and uh what Neon does today? Totally.
Thanks for thanks for having me, Devin.
Uh it's great to be here. It's been
quite a month. Um yeah for us so my
background I've been in fintech working
with e-commerce fintech payment networks
for the better part of the last 101 15
years. I helped build a firm which was a
BNPL startup here in the in the states
that uh works with a lot of e-commerce
merchants like Shopify, Amazon, Walmart
etc.
um worked at Apple Pay somewhat
ironically but briefly um to help them
with some product strategy on their
wallet products and then um helped Rivet
Capital start a new fintech business,
consumer financial services business uh
with and alongside Walmart which is now
called OnePay before founding Neon. So
we we started the idea about four years
ago, officially incorporated the
business in uh 3 years ago, just over 3
years ago now. And the idea has been
then, as it continues to be now, is
building all of the uh payments,
e-commerce, tax compliance, fraud,
orchestration infrastructure that a game
publisher and studio needs to take
advantage of what is now a rapidly
changing environment um around
monetizing their players direct
consumer. So, outside of the app stores,
uh, starting with mobile and PC. Cool.
Could you just quickly kind of go over
what direct to consumer means in terms
of like the context for all of this?
Yeah. So, it can be confusing or a bit
of a misnomer because like aren't aren't
these always sort of direct to consumer?
Depends on who is uh direct and who's
between you and your consumer. The idea
has been I mean for games since
basically the beginning of this industry
uh uh developers, publishers, you've
been suppliers to uh another platform,
right? Whether that's Apple, Google,
Steam, Xbox, PlayStation, Nintendo, uh
the the end consumer has a relationship
primarily with that platform, that
hardware and their device and their
their app store. And the idea has now
been as those as a regulatory um
pressure uh has been opening up the
opportunity for developers to uh
monetize and build a direct relationship
with that consumer without being
intermediated by Apple, Google or the
others others going forward. Then what
does it look like to have the
capabilities to do that? And what does
it mean for your business to have that
direct relationship um that you've
otherwise been been kind of separated
from in the past? Awesome. And it's kind
of ironic too because the direct to
consumer wasn't good before uh and then
it got built up and now it's kind of on
par and now we have this whole situation
where we're at now. But can you just
walk me through like what really
happened? Obviously this has been a long
running case over multiple years but the
big kind of main event uh sort of
concluded or at least partially
concluded at the end of April. Just walk
me through like and and why studios are
excited about this what it really kind
of means to to get started on all this.
Yeah. So maybe I'll give a couple of
points just kind of looking back on the
on the case decisions in the US at least
for simplicity sake over the past few
years. So in 2021 in August, there's a
class action settlement uh sort of as a
sideesideshow from the main Apple Epic
trial of its time then through which
Apple sort of reconfirmed its commitment
to every app developer that they can
have um offplatform or out of app
payment channels, external pay payment
channels. uh that Apple is not entitled
any commission for those purchases
provided that developers were not
linking to them in their games or their
apps or advertising or marketing the
availability of those channels from
within their app. That was in August in
21. Over the years since that point,
which is known as steering, steering,
you know, users to your external
channels, has continued to be litigated.
Uh it was in January of last year 2024
that Apple appealed the the overturning
of that decision to the Supreme Court
saying no no no we don't want to allow
that searing. Still Supreme Court didn't
hear that case. So that meant that in
the US that had to be the case. There
had to be you know Apple had to allow
developers to link and advertise in
their games and in their apps about
external channels. However, uh Apple's
response, which they had very quickly
thereafter, late January, early February
last year, was okay, we'll we'll allow
that, but we're going to basically
require you to get an inapp um linking
entitlement from Apple in order to do
that. And then we are going to charge
27% on all revenue that occurs once a
consumer clicks that link, makes a
purchase on an external channel um over
the course of 7 days. Basically, they
had a lot of stipulations around it. The
point was they were in quote compliance,
but it was not really a good faith
effort to do as the judge intended uh
because the with the amount of friction
sort of the economic penalties of doing
something through their inapp uh link
entitlement made it such that nobody
went through that process. Um so but all
the while I think the most important
part has been you could still have
external channels but the question for
developers and publishers many of our
own uh partners included has been well
then how do I drive awareness of that
channel to my player base uh outside of
the app and that's why the the and I'll
kind of come back to this but the
addressable market for this was somewhat
constrained to core games um casino
games where there's a pretty big and
vibrant community outside of the game
itself in Discord or Facebook groups or
otherwise where you could market this
channel to those players somewhat, you
know, unencumbered, but you're not
reaching the full audience. Now, back to
the ruling in uh on on April 30th of
this year, just about a month ago. Now,
uh that's when Apple came back and said
that no, the 27%
um is not in compliance with what we we
asked you to do or told you to do. Uh
and now as a result as effective
immediately on April 30th in the US all
developers can link to those external
channel channels freely. They can
advertise the those channels freely
within the app and there's no 27%
commission. Nor are there the dreaded
scare screens that Apple had before
which is like you click the link and it
would pop up and say you're going to the
big scary internet you're going to have
your credit card information stolen etc
to dissuade users from doing it. All of
those things are now removed and the
implications are that the like I said
the addressable audience among apps,
developers, games and others is
everybody because now you can drive
awareness in the app freely. You can
embed uh direct checkout links, browser
checkout links like those that we enable
Neon uh to make that purchase directly
without even going to a web store first.
So, it's kind of opening up in in
probably the most significant way since
this opportunity, you know, began. Um,
that's kind of uh enabling true sort of
like multi- channelannel commerce for a
game studio.
Cool. And and I believe I don't know if
this is the term that was actually used
in the um the court settlement, but
definitely used by Epic was malicious
compliance, which was them complying in
the letter of the law technically, but
doing so in a way that was trying to get
people to not actually ever use it. And
of course for for context as well, 27%
is obviously very close to what they
were charging which was 30%. So it was
basically like not only should you not
do this because you're not going to like
save really any money, you're also going
to scare away your customers and
probably lose purchases, right? Lose
money by doing this. And if I understood
right, there was in doing that
entitlement, didn't that also change
your agreement with Apple in terms of
how you're able to do like were you
still able to do Apple Pays like their
their checkout at the same time? like
can you still do that? Can you give uh
players the choice between the two for
people for example that are are
comfortable using Apple's payment rails
and are still unsure especially because
of Apple's scare language uh and don't
want to go the other way. Yeah. So great
question. I
think this has been the uh without
exaggerating the busiest month for our
team since we got started. I we've
flying all over the world. I I think
we've spoken to no fewer than 30 40
different publishers um of varying
sizes, different industries, different
genres of games. Well, now you're
speaking a whole bunch at the same time,
right? I'm speaking a whole bunch at the
same time here. Um but the there's been
a lot of I think consistent questions,
right? I think there's a lot of uh
reactivity that we're seeing around,
okay, now you can do this. What do I do?
How do I do it? Um we have actually been
advising uh uh publishers who work with
a comp with competitors of ours who've
come to us and say like can you go
through my player experience and tell me
like how do I need to fix this to make
it higher converting etc. So there's
just a lot of noise right now in a good
way. Um but I think that to your
question the models that we're seeing
and it's a little early to see how this
will sort of converge are are kind of
three-fold. So the first is which we're
only seeing from reader apps which is
the Apple designation for an app that
has like much thinner margins because
they have licensed content things like
Kindle, Spotify um and others that that
have basically had a carveout for a long
time from the app store where they don't
have to offer in-app purchases, inapp
billing at all. Uh so Spotify before you
could only sign up for a Spotify account
on their website. The difference there
was that you couldn't uh they couldn't
advertise that you can sign up on the
website. Basically, if if you'd never
seen it, it was basically like you get
to their account signup page in the app.
It's like I can't we can't do anything
here. Sorry, that's just the rule. Uh
you go to our website, but they couldn't
link to it. In that case for reader
apps, we're seeing the only using web
payments is still the case. So that's
the first model. Uh but now they can
advertise it in the app itself, right?
So like on Kindle's app, you can click a
link, go make a purchase on Amazon, you
know, on their app or on Amazon.com of
the Kindle content. It will come back in
the the Kindle app itself. Now you
couldn't do that before. And same thing
with Spotify, like you can now see in
the app itself. Um they advertise the
different sort of subscription tiers
that they they offer and you click that
and you go and make a checkout on web.
So again, in that case, it's providing a
lot broader visibility. Um but the
difference there is users already knew
they could only buy it if they went to a
website. So it just kind of reduces the
friction. The other two models that I
think we are seeing that are are most
likely to be I think the popular sort of
um operating model for for games are
what we call uh a hybrid and the the
third is we call user choice which is
basically what Google used to call this
uh user choice billing. Um, user choice
is what if you've seen with Fortnite
back in the app store now, what they're
doing, which is providing the user the
choice for any purchase of either making
inapp purchase um through Apple spilling
system or making a purchase on Epic's
website with Epic Pay or Epic Checkout
and they're going in that case they're
offering 20% cashback rewards. Uh, so
the idea there is we want to um there's
a lot getting into like pricing and
discounting psychology just like in
retail. Um, but in their case, they want
to give a uh the player a reason to go,
like a positive reason to go and make a
purchase through their channel and also
kind of have a credit there for them to
use for that next purchase, too, which
we think is the probably the most right
model depending on what your your
catalog is and and what you sell. And
then the hybrid model is we're seeing a
lot pushing this out right now, some of
our own partners included, where they
will have in the game itself um their
store of their evergreen offers. Uh
those are typically and those will be um
purchasable with inapp purchases going
forward. So think of the types of items
you would buy as an impulse purchase,
right? just like you would for
especially for a casual game or a lower
price point purchase because 30% of 99
cents or $9.99 is a lot better than 30%
of 249 for like a larger offer pack. And
then they'll have a secondary store in
the game uh that is sort of the
exclusive offers and those are only
purchasable through web checkout. And
again, you can layer on incentives like
cash back or credits back or discounts
or extra value, whatever it is. But
having both of those alongside one
another in the game uh allows you to
refresh them over time, but also the
players always know that I go to this
one if I want this and I go to the other
if I want sort of um you know more value
on a web checkout itself. So that's sort
of what we're seeing so far.
So I'm curious on a few things like and
we'll definitely get more into the
detail of like how game developers
should think about this but one thing
that kind of stands out to me is
obviously you know I'm sure this is the
kind of thing Apple would argue is
around convenience of these purchases
and so for example obviously uh you you
pretty much to have an app store account
basically have to have a credit card on
file right so to actually be able to
make even download free stuff you had to
basically so they already kind of have
that in their system also part of you
know country restrictions and stuff like
that so it makes it a lot easier right
in the payment flow because you could
just purchase and like one of those ways
is you know authorizing with a a
fingerprint right or I think Face ID as
well. I'm not I'm not a Apple owner so I
don't know what the current status is
but uh that's something that's that
could be very convenient obviously could
be convenient potentially for you know
other people making purchases on your
phone that you they probably shouldn't
be like kids and things like that but
that is like a very easy payment flow.
uh whereas it seems like that might be
difficult to achieve that same level say
first- time purchasers right when they
go to this external payment flow they're
going to have to provide that
information in new very likely then
there's got to be some I imagine some
way to retain that for future purchases
and that's going to be different per
game right so every game that does that
they might have to provide that
differently depending on if the payment
provider is you know the same and might
sort again I'm not sure what the current
landscape is because it's changing very
rapidly yeah uh but these are these are
problems that I imagine are going to
have to be dealt with and you're I I
seriously doubt you're going to be able
to authorize say with a fingerprint uh
or a face ID to be able to make that
purchase, right? Even in the future
where you let's say you have that credit
card information stored, you don't have
the extra layer perhaps of security. And
again, I'm not arguing for Apple. I'm
just saying that these are definitely
points of friction that people might run
into in making this switch over. And I
mean, there's some ways to think about
that. Uh you know,
just 100%. So the you're right and there
there's a couple of things. App stores
are not going anywhere, right? Like
making inapp purchases on any platform
has a level of convenience. I I worked
there. I understand as you know a part
of the Apple Pay experience itself like
that that is an
insurmountably high um sort of
convenience factor of having inbuilt
embedded payment systems to every
platform PC platforms console platforms
they they could use some improvement on
their checkout products but with Apple
and Google in particular um you're
you're never going to completely reach
parody on the convenience but you can
get quite close so but so the story of
this has been from the very beginning
about friction. It's been about trust
and about friction. Those things are
obviously related. Um so the first
question before all of the inapp linking
and messaging um was possible as of a
month ago, the question is still the
same. How do we um how do we provide the
player as frictionless an experience as
possible? not only about learning about,
you know, that we have a web store, uh,
but when we get them to the web store,
how do we log them in seamlessly?
There's a lot of friction-filled
experiences still out there right now
where people are being forced to copy
and paste a player ID that they didn't
even know they had in the game to like
log into a store. That kills conversion.
Um, the navigation of the store itself,
is it intuitive? Is it easy to find? Is
it clear? And then, of course, a
checkout, right? So, checkout. Um, this
is a very well-worn space in most other
industries, but certainly in e-commerce
and retail, um, which is where a lot of
our time is, our team has spent time
prior to Neon. And exactly to your
point, checkout has to be as high
converting as possible. So then the
question is, how do you do that? There
there's a a few things. First, the
question of conversion has a lot of
elements to it, but you can think about
it as a few variables. First, you have
the breadth of payment options available
that a player might want to use to make
a purchase. If you don't, they might not
convert. So, that's really important for
a business like us to have as as broad
and as deep a support of payment
methods, global payment methods, local
wallets. They're very hard to combine
and integrate unless you have sort of
relationships there, etc. because
different people pay in different ways
in different parts of the world. The
second is uh for those card payments to
your point where it might you want to
make that an option for players. But if
it's asking them to reinput their card
details, how do you make that as
seamless as possible? There's easy ways
of doing that, too. I mean, a lot of
people have their card details already
stored in their Safari browser or their
Chrome browser. Uh so you can autopop
populate that for the first time. uh for
a publisher, if you're not going to
build this stuff internally, you need to
make sure your partner is PCI compliant,
which is the payment card industry
standard that we have to be compliant
within in order to save that card
information for second time like
one-click purchase. But you want to make
that as seamless as possible as well.
And then the third is we still support
Apple Pay. We support Google Pay and
PayPal and other sort of one-click uh
checkout wallets on our web checkout and
our our um our web stores. So, even when
you get there, that's still a familiar
wallet and it's still a one-click
purchase, even if it isn't in the game
itself, right? If and until that opens
up. Um, but all of that it's it's a part
of the the broader arc around endtoend
conversion of an e-commerce experience
that now you can drive from directly in
the game and collapse some of those
friction points to basically the
checkout itself. Um, while I'd say maybe
the last point on conversion is giving
the player a clear reason why they
should use this web checkout. And we've
seen a lot of mistakes over the last
like couple weeks where uh, you know,
some developers would just kind of like
jam a um, you know, buy a buy button in
the game now uh, to to redirect them to
make a purchase on the browser, but
they're not converting. They don't know
why. Why would I do this? Why are you
forcing me to do this? Why wouldn't you
at least tell me like, am I going to get
more value there? am I at a good you
know cash back etc. That is certainly a
critical component to this whole
conversion funnel as well in general
like when consumers are asking like
what's in this for me like this case how
does this help me like outside of the
epic thing which is obviously like
they're trying to do the cash back in
general like why should consumers care
about this why does this benefit them
when they're having to go through extra
hurdles potentially. Yeah. So it's
that's such a fascinating question
because I think a little bit of our sort
of like advising with our current
partners and and others that you know
that we're we're in conversations with
it kind of boils down
to you have to implement irrespective of
the the endless unfolding of regulatory
decisions. This the dominoes will
continue to fall. It's just a matter of
how quickly and what they mean. The the
point is you still need to be sort of
first principles thoughtful of your
players experience in the game, what you
want them to know about this web
channel, when they should go there, what
it's for relative to the inapp
purchases, etc. And like just define
that as a starting point, as sort of a
blueprint from which you build in the
experience itself. And and I think
fundamental to that is uh what if
anything are you going to tell your
players about why this thing is here?
Now in the early early days of sort of
web stores in 2021 and two um it was
fascinating to see you know in Discord
channels for instance you would like you
know search web store and and some of
the bigger publishers are doing this
just to see what players are talking
about and across the board we we we
pulled a lot of this information and
screenshots down. There's a lot of like
gamers are very savvy people. They're
very tech-savvy people. They're very
smart. they understand that there's some
reason for this, but unless you tell
them, they just assuming. So, we would
see all this chatter. It's like, well,
why are they doing this? Well, Apple
takes too much money uh and they're
trying to save money. So, it's like a
cost-saving thing. And you'd have
somebody else chime in. Well, if if
they're saving money by me making a
purchase through this, I should get
something out of it. Why isn't it a
better discount? So, you people are
going to create the story, your players
are going to create the story unless you
own the narrative. And it's a very
simple narrative to own, right? like
this exists. The analogy I I gave a lot
early on for why we're doing what we're
doing and sort of the bet that we're
making is the same dynamic happened in
retail visa v Amazon in the mid to late
2000s. Uh merchants sold on Amazon. They
took a very heavy commission on that.
They did a lot for you. They own the
consumer relationship. Consumer had
their payment details on file with
Amazon, etc. And it wasn't until things
like Shopify and Stripe and Addy and all
these sort of like enabling pieces of
direct consumer commerce in that world
came about that a merchant could now
complement Amazon distribution with
their own first party channel. But they
the same problem. Why what do I tell my
user my my consumer in that case um
about my Shopify store versus Amazon,
right? what do I want them to know about
this relative to that so that it can
begin to sort of uh condition and
habituate that that experience. The same
is true here. You have to be intentional
and thoughtful with your user. Doesn't
need to be like a massive investment,
just a pop-up modal, right? Or like a
banner on the store itself or a banner
in that that like web exclusive store
within your game. Like why does this
thing exist? And the the beautiful thing
uh is that for those that have told
their players why 30% is very expensive
uh it's it's not really sustainable for
our business model by using direct
you're supporting our business. They
love that and they support it and like
as anyone would because you really for
the most part you really want the the
the company that makes the game that you
love so much successful, right? So it
it's just about being intentional and
and the messaging being clear. Yeah, I
can imagine any messaging gaps where
there's just not enough clarity on why
it's happening. Just lead to conspiracy
theories and especially players
thinking, you know, always always the
first jump with any monetization is
greed, right? The company's being
greedy. They just want to make more
money. They're not going to spend this
on making the game better. They're
probably going to fire people and switch
to AI. All those kind of like, right? Uh
but I got to imagine it's still hard to
communicate whatever you want to
communicate to an audience that may not
be reading. uh yeah readily right they
may be like into the gameplay they don't
want to read I mean obviously different
audiences and all that but that is a
problem right where you have people
skipping things not wanting to read
stuff or hey it's it is fault small font
on a tiny screen uh you know where
people just might skip it and it's like
you could have to have like intro videos
explaining it or you and all the
different messaging channels you might
have to put that on you're talking about
Discord okay that's one thing you've got
a community manager maybe communicating
that on there to like the five people
that are actively reading and it's it's
got to be like very fragmented and a
situation where it's very easy for them
to run into a situation where they just
imagine what the the truth is. And
you've got freeto-play players that love
to brag about it and self-justify it.
And I got to imagine that only fuels
that where they're like, "Oh, now the
company wants this greedy thing where
they're not taking a cut. Like, I was
happy to give Apple by 30% cuz they
built this phone or whatever and like
and now this company wants all my money
and like I'm I'm going to be absolutely
free to play now. I'm totally not going
to spend a dime." Yeah. Yeah. No, you're
right. I I think which is why just like
Amazon's not going anywhere, right?
You're the as you as you run this
forward, um well, let me let me go back
to the retail case. If you look at how
retail e-commerce has evolved over the
last 15 years, basically like since this
advent of direct consumer really took
hold for the the the businesses that
have um their first party direct channel
and continue to sell on um
Amazon, depending on how um they've
invested in those channels over the
year, the the revenue breakdown ends up
being around 6040 direct to third party,
you know, direct to Amazon or 7030 some
even higher. But the point there is
there's always going to be a consumer
that only wants to make a purchase
through Apple and Google and Steam and
Xbox. And there's certainly going to be
